intro: Cynoglossum nebrodense subsp. lucanum, commonly known as the Sicilian bellflower, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to southern Europe. It belongs to the Boraginaceae family and is characterized by its hairy stems and showy blue to purple flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or limestone soils and thrives in full sun to partial shade. Its leaves are lance-shaped and often have a slightly rough texture, while its flowers bloom in late summer. This subspecies is notable for its ornamental value and is occasionally cultivated in gardens.
